title: Building Production Micro-Agents
description: Master the art of building small, focused agents that do one thing exceptionally well. Learn to compose micro-agents into robust systems and find the bleeding edge of what's possible with current LLMs.
objectives: Understand why small agents with 3-10 steps outperform complex orchestrations
Learn to identify and extract micro-agent boundaries from monolithic workflows
Master the composition patterns for connecting micro-agents
Implement production-grade monitoring and observability for agent systems
Find and push the bleeding edge of LLM capabilities
prerequisites: Completion of Module 1: Rethinking Agents as Software
Familiarity with observability tools (logs, metrics, traces)
author: Brandon J. Redmond

questions.question: What's the ideal number of steps for a micro-agent?
questions.explanation: 3-10 steps hits the sweet spot: complex enough to be useful, simple enough to be reliable and maintainable.

questions.question: Why do micro-agents outperform monolithic agents in production?
options: They're easier to debug, test, and maintain
questions.explanation: Micro-agents excel because each one can be debugged, tested, and optimized independently. When something goes wrong, you know exactly which agent and which step failed.

questions.question: What does 'finding the bleeding edge' mean in agent development?
options: Finding tasks just beyond current reliability and engineering them to work
Pushing agents to their breaking point
questions.explanation: The bleeding edge is where you take something LLMs can almost do reliably and engineer your system to make it work consistentlyâ€”creating capabilities others can't achieve.
